pull.title: ci: Switch all Linux builds to Debian and more improvements

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: 658faf66f757105280b021d0d0aba697bfce4f73 looks good to me mod comment

events.message:
ci: Switch all Linux builds to Debian

The experiment of using Nix Shell was not really successful. Most
notably, Nix uses a bunch of wrapper scripts around compilers, which
make the build much less "pure". This may be useful but it's exactly
not what we want for CI. In particular, this resulted in gcc being used
for the "clang" builds because a wrapper script redefined the CC env
variable.

This now builds a single docker image (Debian) for all architectures
that we test in CI on Linux.
ci: Print information about binaries using "file"

ci: Run PRs on merge result instead of on the source branch

This is taken from Bitcoin Core's .cirrus.yml
ci: Split output of logs into multiple sections

ci: Select number of parallel make jobs depending on CI environment

This should improve compilation times on macOS. Things can certainly
be improved further, e.g., by running the benchmarks in parallel.

comments.body: Hm, your new `file` invocations shows that this actually builds 64-bit binaries https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5529748383203328?command=test#L212. Not sure if this is missing the `-m32` flag or if the automake `--host` option should have set that.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -25,14 +21,19 @@ sed -i'' -e 's@/usr/bin/file@$(which file)@g' configure
     --with-valgrind="$WITH_VALGRIND" \
     --host="$HOST" $EXTRAFLAGS
 
+make -j2
+
+# Print information about binaries so that we can see that the architecture is correct
+file ./*tests || true
+file ./bench_* || true
+
 if [ -n "$BUILD" ]
 then
-    make -j2 "$BUILD"
+    make "$BUILD"

comments.body:
Hm damn, I played a lot with this, and in the end I thought it works without the `-m32` flag. I'll have a look... 

By the way, a difference to the previous approach on Debian (what we had on Travis) is that this here doesn't use gcc-multilib because this is not compatible with installing the other s390x compiler (okay we could have two images) and I generally considered it to be more consistent: "multilib" is a thing we anyway can do only on x86(_64) and not for s390x (and arm and more archs, which we hopefully can add now by basically copy and paste).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -25,14 +21,19 @@ sed -i'' -e 's@/usr/bin/file@$(which file)@g' configure
     --with-valgrind="$WITH_VALGRIND" \
     --host="$HOST" $EXTRAFLAGS
 
+make -j2
+
+# Print information about binaries so that we can see that the architecture is correct
+file ./*tests || true
+file ./bench_* || true
+
 if [ -n "$BUILD" ]
 then
-    make -j2 "$BUILD"
+    make "$BUILD"
comments.body:
Oh yeah, so the call to `make` doing the actual compilation now is a few linesabove.

But yeah, `$BUILD` is usually `check` here and this can run in parallel too: https://www.gnu.org/software/automake/manual/html_node/Parallel-Test-Harness.html So we should probably do this. In fact, we should have maybe have -j13 or probably set it cleverly because on Linux we ask for 1 CPU but on MacOS we always get 12 CPUs.
Ok, the issue was indeed that we set `CC` explicitly to `gcc`. When it's not set, configure finds the right `i686-linux-gn-gcc`. I've set it explicitly to `i686-linux-gnu-gcc` now.

     --with-valgrind="$WITH_VALGRIND" \

+make -j2
+
+# Print information about binaries so that we can see that the architecture is correct
+file ./*tests || true

+
 if [ -n "$BUILD" ]
 then
-    make -j2 "$BUILD"
+    make "$BUILD"
comments.body: I changed the existing commit not to remove -j2 and I added a commit that improves parallelism on macOS. This can be improved further when we overhaul the CI script.
Yup, thanks that appears to work.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,26 +16,38 @@ env:
   CTIMETEST: yes
   BENCH: yes
   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2

@@ -16,26 +16,38 @@ env:
   CTIMETEST: yes
   BENCH: yes
   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2
comments.body:
`MAKEFLAGS` is a way to set flags for `make` globally. `make` will pick this up. See in 5.7.3 ian the manual (https://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/make.html#index-MAKEFLAGS) or in Appendix A:

> The MAKEFLAGS variable can also be useful if you want to have certain options, such as -k (see Summary of Options), set each time you run make. You simply put a value for MAKEFLAGS in your environment.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,26 +16,38 @@ env:
   CTIMETEST: yes
   BENCH: yes
   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2
comments.body: ugh but now I need to remove `-j2`  from the invocations in the script... Sorry, I screwed up with too many fixups  and squashes

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,26 +16,38 @@ env:
   CTIMETEST: yes
   BENCH: yes
   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2
comments.body: Ah appendix A is helpful. The first sentence in the manual is "Flags [...] are passed automatically to the sub-make through the variable MAKEFLAGS." which would make this use of MAKEFLAGS rather esoteric.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,26 +16,38 @@ env:
   CTIMETEST: yes
   BENCH: yes
   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2
comments.body:
Yeah, I admit the docs are somewhat obscure. (Maybe this was introduced as a way to pass stuff to sub-makes but it's widely used to specify -j2 for example, and there's nothing wrong with that.) See also POSIX: https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/make.html

I'll update once again to remove the explicit flags from the command line.

comments.diff_hunk:

   CTIMETEST: yes

   ITERS: 2
-  # We only need the top commit
-  CIRRUS_CLONE_DEPTH: 1
+  MAKEFLAGS: -j2

@@ -21,22 +21,27 @@ valgrind --version || true
     --with-valgrind="$WITH_VALGRIND" \
     --host="$HOST" $EXTRAFLAGS
 
+make -j2
+
+# Print information about binaries so that we can see that the architecture is correct
+file *tests || true

@@ -21,22 +21,27 @@ valgrind --version || true
     --with-valgrind="$WITH_VALGRIND" \
     --host="$HOST" $EXTRAFLAGS
 
+make -j2
+
+# Print information about binaries so that we can see that the architecture is correct
+file *tests || true
comments.body: Otherwise the statement will fail if the wildcard does not match anything, and the files may not exist in every job. This is a little bit more meaningful in the line below when checking for benchmarks (because we have jobs with benchmarks disabled). But I just thought it's more consistent to apply the `|| true` in every line. In the future we may have special jobs without tests enabled (cttimetests only etc.)
